entries.name: Wide Shot (WS)
entries.description: Shows the subject and their environment. Establishes the scene and provides context.

entries.name: Full Shot (FS)
entries.description: Frames the character from head to toe, with their full body in the frame.

entries.name: Medium Shot (MS)
entries.description: Shows the subject from the waist up. Focuses on the character but still shows some environment.

entries.name: Close-Up (CU)
entries.description: Frames a subject's head and shoulders. Used to show detailed facial expressions and emotions.

entries.name: Extreme Close-Up (ECU)
entries.description: Frames a single detail, like a person's eyes or mouth, to create intimacy or tension.

entries.name: Eye-Level
entries.description: The most neutral angle, simulating a normal human viewpoint.

entries.name: High-Angle
entries.description: The camera looks down on the subject, often making them seem small or vulnerable.

entries.name: Low-Angle
entries.description: The camera looks up at the subject, making them appear powerful, heroic, or intimidating.

entries.name: Dutch Angle
entries.description: The camera is tilted on its axis, creating a sense of unease, disorientation, or madness.

entries.name: Pan
entries.description: The camera swivels horizontally on a fixed axis. Used to follow a subject or scan a scene.

entries.name: Tilt
entries.description: The camera swivels vertically on a fixed axis. Used to look up or down at a subject or object.

entries.name: Dolly / Tracking
entries.description: The entire camera moves forward, backward, or alongside the subject on a track or dolly.

entries.name: Crane / Jib
entries.description: The camera is mounted on an arm and moves vertically through space for dramatic effect.

entries.name: Rule of Thirds
entries.description: Divide your frame into a 3x3 grid. Place key points of interest on the intersections or along the lines.

entries.name: Leading Lines
entries.description: Use natural lines in the scene (roads, fences, etc.) to guide the viewer's eye to your subject.

entries.name: Framing
entries.description: Use elements in the foreground (windows, doorways) to create a natural frame around your subject.

entries.name: Headroom
entries.description: The space between the top of a subject's head and the top of the frame. Avoid too much or too little.
